title: Vanna 2.0 Explained for Business Users
content:
Think of Vanna 2.0 as

When you build an AI agent for just yourself, you don’t worry about:

Who can see what data

Who has permission to do what

Tracking who did what and when

How the AI sees data versus how users see it

But when you build an AI agent for your company,

Vanna 2.0 makes this automatic. Instead of spending months adding user permissions and building separate outputs for the AI versus the user interface, it’s built-in from day one.

Most AI agent frameworks are built for demos—one user, no security concerns, no real data. When companies try to deploy these to real users, they hit a wall:

Companies end up spending

Vanna 2.0 solves both problems:

Every action an agent takes automatically knows:

This isn’t something you configure—it’s impossible to build an agent in Vanna 2.0

When your agent queries a database and gets 10,000 rows:

Why does this matter?

Your AI processes faster and costs less (it’s not reading 10,000 rows)

Your users get rich, interactive experiences (not just text summaries)

You don’t have to build this yourself—it happens automatically

You’re building an AI agent that will have multiple users with different permissions

You need database queries, file access, or API calls to respect user boundaries

You want to go from prototype to production without rewriting everything

Other frameworks make it easy to build a demo.

If you’re building an AI agent for your company, your customers, or your users—not just for yourself—Vanna 2.0 is built for you.
